I absolutely adore this time of year and I love where I live, right next to the Phoenix Park.  I am blessed to see the sights I see whilst walking my Irish Setter, Senna, each morning.  This is one of those sights.  I hope you enjoy.  The shot was taken with a long lens so I was not close to these beautiful creatures.

The monOrchid is a 16,000 creative colab building where photographers, film-makers, architects, designers, artists and more work and create the perfect atmosphere for creative industries.Located in the heart of the arts district in downtown Phoenix, the monOrchid building offers work space for events, photo/video production, art exhibits and small businesses. The monOrchid is a 14,000 sq ft space comprised of open exhibition space, office pods, and two world-class cycloramas. The varied connected spaces house multiple creative businesses and offer unique settings for cultural events within the masonry walls and soaring natural wood bow trusses. Originally a warehouse constructed in 1937 by Del Webb, the building is an excellent example of adaptive-reuse in the City’s core. Through ten years of renovation and invention, the building has morphed into a place for collaboration, creativity and celebration.

Wayne Rainey has been creating and showing his photography and film work for 25 years and has been featured in Art in America, Artnews, Communication Arts, Photo District News, the New York Times the Los Angeles Times among others.

recommendations: Justin Germain
Art Business Marketing and PR Specialist, Curator, Critic, Owner of Art(ist)serv, and Museum Professional
December 6, 2014, Justin reported directly to Wayne

Wayne is a catalyst for growth in downtown Phoenix.  He is one of the most relentless advocates for the creative class and the importance of the arts for the future development for the city.  I have never been around a more inspiring individual and it was an honor to work with him at the monOrchid and creating the infrastructure for the art program through Shade Projects!  We had some great exhibitions and events and created some amazing partnerships and relationships together!  In 20 years we will all look and back and reminisce and know that we were there.  Your skills as a director were crucial in creating the Thermal PHX show and I can't wait to see what we did.  Thanks for all your work and support Wayne, you are the man!

summary: Wayne Rainey has been creating and managing commercial and  artistic campaigns in Phoenix and abroad for over 25 years now and has continued to be recognized for his work. As an artist, Rainey strives to capture the essence of a place, its inhabitants and the special quality that drew him to the subject matter in the first place. In his commercial work, he constantly challenges the nature of advertising and seeks to explore the nuances of the core message of each campaign. Awards/Articles and Accolades includePhoto District News, Photo Annual Finalist, February 2013Top 100 Creatives New times 2013NY Post, ‘Rising High’, 2005Photo District News, ‘The Fifty States Issue’, February 2005NY Times, Bentley Gallery Exhibition Review, January 2003ArtNews, Bentley Gallery Exhibition Review, January 2003Photo District News, Judges Choice Award, 2003Juxtaposed, Holgas Featured, April 2002Phoenix Arts Commission commissioner 2001-2004Communication Arts, Award of Excellence, 1998Addy Award, Public Service Division, 1998Addy Award, Multiple Media Business to Consumer, 1998His latest projects include producing and directing videos for Renaissance Hotels, Bison Made, and the documentary for The Feast On the Streets and photographic assignments for Tuft and Needle, and directing and producing a massive art installation video feature in the lobby if the new State Farm National HQ in Tempe Az.
name: Wayne Rainey
